Afghanistan: First Anglo-Afghan War: A British expeditionary force captured Quetta.
Argentina: Rosas made Supreme Chief of the Argentine Confederation
Australia: Paul Edmund Strzelecki became the first European to ascend and name Australia's highest peak, Mount Kosciuszko. HMS Beagle sailed into Darwin Harbour during its surveying of the area. John Clements Wickham named the area Port Darwin in honour of their former shipmate Charles Darwin. The settlement became the town of Palmerston in 1869 and was renamed Darwin in 1911.
Belgium:
The Kingdom of the Netherlands recognises Belgian independence.
Treaty of London signed, finalising international guarantees of Belgian independence and neutrality.
Chile: Battle of Yungay and defeat of the Confederation.
China: Destruction of opium at Humen: The Qing Imperial Commissioner Lin Zexu ordered the destruction of roughly a thousand tons of opium seized from EIC merchants in Humen.
Colombia: The War of the Supremes (Spanish: Guerra de los Supremos, also called the Guerra de los Conventos) extended from 1839 to 1841, caused by the ambitions of various regional leaders (gamonales) to seize power and depose President José Ignacio de Márquez
France: Pastry War: Victorious French troops withdraw from Mexico after their demands were satisfied.
Germany: Belgium, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Austria, France, Russia and the German Confederation signed the Treaty of London, recognizing Belgium's independence and guaranteeing its neutrality.
Peru: The Peru-Bolivian Confederacy was officially dissolved.
Taiwan: Qing authorities demarcate Chinese territories in Taiwan and prohibit Chinese settlers from encroaching on native lands
